claim:
All statistical analyses were performed using SigmaPlot 14 (Systat Software, Inc., San Jose, CA).RESULTS
Overall Reporting Compliance of Study Experimental Variables
The average combined reporting compliance of all variables is presented in Figure 1.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Overall compliance percentage as a function of year of publication of organismal animal physiology articles (n = 84) published in five different journals: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B, Journal of Physiology, Journal of Experimental Biology, American Journal of Physiology—Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative, and Frontiers in Physiology. See methods for additional details. Capital letters indicate significant differences among years. Mean value for decade group 2018–2020 (n = 45) is significantly higher than decade group 2008–2010 (n = 39; P = 0.001).

claim: The distribution of variables reported above and below average reporting compliance levels shows a clear pattern with regard to variable category (Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Overall reporting compliance of 34 commonly reported experimental variables, from highest to lowest compliance relative to mean compliance of ∼63%. Data are grouped into data collection variables (gray), innate biological variables (red), and experimental condition variables (blue) and are likely to affect physiological processes and, consequently, the reported results. Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.

claim: The 10 variables with lowest reporting compliance, on the other hand, comprise almost exclusively innate biological as well as experimental condition variables (Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Overall reporting compliance of 34 commonly reported experimental variables, from highest to lowest compliance relative to mean compliance of ∼63%. Data are grouped into data collection variables (gray), innate biological variables (red), and experimental condition variables (blue) and are likely to affect physiological processes and, consequently, the reported results. Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.

claim: As another example of a variable that may just be viewed as “not worth reporting,” the prandial state of experimental animals was underreported compared with many more overtly controlled variables (Fig. 2, Supplemental Table S1).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Overall reporting compliance of 34 commonly reported experimental variables, from highest to lowest compliance relative to mean compliance of ∼63%. Data are grouped into data collection variables (gray), innate biological variables (red), and experimental condition variables (blue) and are likely to affect physiological processes and, consequently, the reported results. Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.

claim: The distribution of variables reporting compliance levels shows a clear pattern with regard to variable category (Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Overall reporting compliance of 34 commonly reported experimental variables, from highest to lowest compliance relative to mean compliance of ∼63%. Data are grouped into data collection variables (gray), innate biological variables (red), and experimental condition variables (blue) and are likely to affect physiological processes and, consequently, the reported results. Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.

claim: Somewhat encouragingly, however, the year 2020 shows significantly higher reporting compliance (Fig. 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Overall compliance percentage as a function of year of publication of organismal animal physiology articles (n = 84) published in five different journals: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B, Journal of Physiology, Journal of Experimental Biology, American Journal of Physiology—Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative, and Frontiers in Physiology. See methods for additional details. Capital letters indicate significant differences among years. Mean value for decade group 2018–2020 (n = 45) is significantly higher than decade group 2008–2010 (n = 39; P = 0.001).
